EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
MCCAIN FOODS USA, INC
RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM REPORT

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICY AT MCCAIN FOODS 
The objective of the risk management plan (RMP), as stated in part 68 of the Clean Air Act (CAA), is to prevent accidental releases of substances that can cause serious harm to the public and the environment from short-term exposure and to mitigate the severity of releases that do occur. To meet this objective McCain Foods USA, Inc. (McCain Foods) has developed a Hazard Assessment detailing the potential effects of an accidental release; provided an accident history of the last five years; completed an evaluation of worst-case and alternative accidental releases; documented McCain Foods¿ Prevention Program that includes safety precautions and maintenance, monitoring, and employee training measures; and, developed an outline McCain Foods Emergency Response Program that spells out emergency health care, employee training measures and procedures for informing the public and response agencies (e.g. the fire department) should an accident occur. 

McCain Foods utilizes and stores anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant, which makes it necessary to observe certain safety precautions during ammonia use to prevent human exposure, reduce the threat to workers¿ personal health, the surrounding community and the environment.  It is McCain Foods¿ policy to adhere to all applicable federal and state regulations.  Safety depends directly on the proper handling of ammonia combined with the safety devices that are incorporated in our facility and the safe handling procedures that personnel are trained in.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED
McCain Foods located at 801 Rockwell Avenue in Fort Atkinson, Wisconsin, is a food product manufacturing facility with approximately 350 employees.  McCain Foods is required to develop and implement a RMP as issued by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), based on exceedence of t

hreshold quantities for the handling, use, and storage of anhydrous ammonia as listed in 40 CFR 68.130.  McCain Foods¿ production of frozen foods utilizes anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant.  

Anhydrous ammonia, readily recognized by its distinctive odor, is a compressed gas with extremely toxic vapors which irritate the eyes and skin. Although classified as non-flammable by the DOT, in confined spaces anhydrous ammonia can accumulate to a flammable concentration and create an explosive environment.
Exposure pathways for anhydrous ammonia include inhalation which may cause irritation, lack of sense of smell, nausea, vomiting, chest pain, difficulty breathing, head ache, lung damage, and long-term inhalation can cause digestive disorders; eyes which causes irritation, frostbite, tearing, blindness, and glaucoma; skin which may cause severe irritation, blisters, and frostbite; and ingestion which may cause irritation, difficulty breathing, and kidney damage. 
Inventory of anhydrous ammonia at McCain Foods is equal to 37,633 pounds (lbs.) throughout the entire system which includes the following vessels with associated maximum anhydrous ammonia capacities:  
Outside High Pressure Receiver ¿ 13,783 lbs.
Outside Intercooler ¿ 11,661 lbs.
FES Recirculator ¿ 4,179 lbs.
RECO ¿40 Recirculator ¿ 3,692 lbs.
FES Intercooler ¿ 1,582 lbs.
Vilter Recirulator ¿ 1,368 lbs.
RECO ¿20 Recirculator ¿ 1,368 lbs.

Potential hazards that could lead to an accidental release include, but are not limited to, equipment failure, damage to piping, damage to equipment, and human error.    

WORST-CASE SCENARIO AND ALTERNATE RELEASE SCENARIO
The worst-case scenario is based on an event that would emit the largest quantity of anhydrous ammonia, which at McCain Foods would be a release from the outside high pressure receiver vessel located outside the McCain Foods¿ machine room, exterior of the building.  Maximum capacity for the outside high pressure receiver vessel is 13,783 pounds and continuous

release rate is 1378.3 pounds per minute (lbs/min).  EPA¿s Arial Locations of Hazardous Atmospheres (ALOHA 5.2.3) Model was used to determine a maximum threat zone of 3.1 miles for the ammonia level of concern (LOC) or ammonia IDLH of 300 parts-per-million (ppm).

An "alternate release scenario" model should be a release that not necessarily would cause the next greatest release of ammonia, but would be the most likely event to occur.  McCain Foods¿ alternate release scenario is a release of ammonia vapor from a safety relief valve due to an over-pressurization condition on a vertical vessel located within the McCain Foods facility machine room.  Maximum release quantity is 195 pounds and continuous release rate is 36 lbs/min from the safety relief valve.  EPA¿s ALOHA 5.2.3 Model was manipulated to determine a maximum threat zone of 198 yards for the ammonia LOC of 300 ppm.   

Release duration and atmospheric information for the worst-case and alternate release scenarios were based on EPA¿s Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration (40 CFR Part 68).  

The following administrative and engineering controls are in place at the McCain Foods facility to limit the distance for the reported scenarios:

·	Electronic ammonia detection in machine room, outside in main relief headers, and on roof by safety relief discharge ventilation.  Audible and flashing alarms are located in both the maintenance and production areas.
·	High-level liquid switches are configured to all pressure vessels which will shut down compressor operation during an abnormal level condition.
·	Safety relief valves are installed on all pressure vessels, condensers and compressor oil separators to eliminate over pressurization conditions in those associated pieces of equipment.
·	Periodic Maintenance Program is in place within the maintenance department to ensure all refrigeration components are kept in optimum operating status.  

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The gene

ral accidental release prevention program at McCain Foods includes:
·	Regular completion of a process hazard analysis.
·	Use of process controls such as vents, relief valves, check valves, manual/automatic shutoff, interlocks, alarms and procedures, backup pump, and purge system.
o	Electronic ammonia detection in machine room, outside in main relief headers, and on roof by safety relief discharge ventilation.  Audible and flashing alarms are located in both the maintenance and production areas.
o	High-level liquid switches are configured to all pressure vessels which will shut down compressor operation during an abnormal level condition.
o	Safety relief valves are installed on all pressure vessels, condensers and compressor oil separators to eliminate over pressurization conditions in those associated pieces of equipment.
·	Use of mitigation systems to include sprinkler system, firewalls, enclosure, and wastewater collection.
·	Periodic Maintenance Program is in place within the maintenance department to ensure all refrigeration components are kept in optimum operating status.  
·	Training programs and frequent review of these programs.  
·	Regular compliance audits.  

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

McCain has no accidental releases to report over the last five years.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The purpose of the McCain Foods Emergency Response Program is to:

·	Minimize exposure to employees and the surrounding community in the event of a hazardous material release or spill.
·	Assure the safe emergency evacuation of the plant in the instance that it is required.
·	Provide for prompt medical attention to any employees who become seriously injured or ill at work.
·	Manage an emergency response system and coordinate response of the internal and external resources required to provide efficient and effective response to any type of emergency that may occur at McCain Foods.

McCain Foods updated their Emergency Action Plan (EAP) as part of the Emergency Response Program

\par }{The general accidental release prevention program at McCain Foods includes:

Electronic ammonia detection in machine room, outside in main relief headers, and on roof by safety relief discharge ventilation.  Audible and flashing alarms are located in both the maintenance and production areas.

b7\tab}}\pard \s16\qj \fi-360\li720\ri0\widctlpar\jclisttab\tx720\aspalpha\aspnum\faauto\ls2\adjustright\rin0\lin720\itap0 {
Use of mitigation systems to include sprinkler system, firewalls, enclosure, and wastewater collection.

\par }{\b\scaps Five-Year Accident History
\par }{
\par McCain has no accidental releases to report over the last five years.
\par 
\par }{\b\scaps Emergency Response Program
\par }{
\par The purpose of the McCain Foods Emergency Response Program is to:
\par 
\par {\listtext\pard\plain\s16 \f3\fs22 \loch\af3\dbch\af0\hich\f3 \'b7\tab}}\pard \s16\qj \fi-360\li720\ri0\widctlpar\jclisttab\tx720\aspalpha\aspnum\faauto\ls3\adjustright\rin0\lin720\itap0 {
Minimize exposure to employees and the surrounding community in the event of a hazardous material release or spill.
\par {\listtext\pard\plain\s16 \f3\fs22 \loch\af3\dbch\af0\hich\f3 \'b7\tab}Assure the safe emergency evacuation of the plant in the instance that it is required.
\par {\listtext\pard\plain\s16 \f3\fs22 \loch\af3\dbch\af0\hich\f3 \'b7\tab}Provide for prompt medical attention to any employees who become seriously injured or ill at work.
\par {\listtext\pard\plain\s16 \f3\fs22 \loch\af3\dbch\af0\hich\f3 \'b7\tab}Manage an emergency response system and coordinate response of the internal and external re
sources required to provide efficient and effective response to any type of emergency that may occur at McCain Foo

ds.
\par }\pard \s16\qj \li0\ri0\widctlpar\aspalpha\aspnum\faauto\adjustright\rin0\lin0\itap0 {
\par McCain Foods updated their Emergency Action Plan (EAP) as part of the Emergency Response Program in August 2003.  Objective of the EAP is
 to ensure the safety of all employees of McCain Foods, as established in compliance with 29 CFR 1910.38 of the OSHA General Industry Standards.  McCain Foods has received input from and worked with the Fort Atkinson Fire Department, Jefferson County Loca
l Emergency Planning Committees (LEPC) and State of Wisconsin HAZMAT organizations to ensure compliance in the emergency response areas.  
\par 
\par }{\b\scaps Planned Changes to Improve Safety
\par }{
\par McCain Foods conducts a monthly meeting to review ammonia system, document unsafe conditions, and discuss improvements to equipment.  A $30,000 budget is set aside for review of the system and any necessary improvements.  In addition, valves are checked a
nnually and equipment is calibrated every six months, both are conducted by an outside agency.      
\par 
\par }\pard\plain \qj \li0\ri10\sb100\sa100\sbauto1\saauto1\widctlpar\tx9350\aspalpha\aspnum\faauto\adjustright\rin10\lin0\itap0 \fs24\lang1033\langfe1033\cgrid\langnp1033\langfenp1033 {\fs22 
\par }}
